author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Divorce Rates Are Down, for Now.
description: And: Another almost relationship.
content: If the pandemic has done one good thing, it‚Äôs given some couples the opportunity to work through their differences. In many states across the country, divorce rates have dropped considerably in the past year. Some divorce lawyers and relationship experts credit uncertainty, financial concerns and more time spent together as a few of the reasons couples aren‚Äôt calling it quits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: In Washington, Policy Revolves Around Joe Manchin. He Likes It That Way.
description: Mr. Manchin‚Äôs belief in the need to keep the filibuster has set the stage for a collision between Democrats eager to use its majorities to pass sweeping legislation and a political throwback determined to restore bipartisanship.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî If Democrats eliminate the filibuster, there is one senator who would have an outsized impact in the 50-50 chamber on issues that could reshape the nation‚Äôs future: infrastructure, immigration, gun laws and voting rights. That senator is Joe Manchin III of West Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Dozens Are Gunned Down in ‚ÄòDay of Shame‚Äô for Myanmar
description: A rights group said it had documented 90 killings by the security forces on Saturday. It appeared to be the bloodiest day since protests against the military coup began.
content: On the eve of a major military celebration, Myanmar‚Äôs army warned people not to come out to protest or they could be shot ‚Äúin the back,‚Äù or in the head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Modi‚Äôs Visit to Bangladesh Sets Off Violent Protests
description: At least four people were killed in clashes between the police and demonstrators, who have denounced Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina for inviting India‚Äôs leader.
content: DHAKA, Bangladesh ‚Äî At least four people were killed and dozens injured in violent protests in Bangladesh on Friday, set off by the arrival of Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India to mark 50 years since Bangladesh gained independence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz, Sof√≠a Villamil and Federico Rios
title: Children Trapped by Colombia‚Äôs War, Five Years After Peace Deal
description: Despite a 2016 peace deal with the FARC, Colombia‚Äôs long internal conflict continues. Seldom has that been as evident as this month, when the government bombed a rebel camp full of young people.
content: PUERTO CACHICAMO, Colombia ‚Äî At 13, she left home to join the guerrillas. Now, at 15, Yeimi Sof√≠a Vega lay in a coffin, killed during a military operation ordered by her government.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Children Trapped in Crossfire as War Drags On in Colombia
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 27, 2021.
content: ‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt create change, if there is no investment, no other vision for our sons and daughters, we are going to fill our cemeteries with children.‚Äù
source.name: The New York Times

title: Treat Yourself
description: Melissa Clark‚Äôs lemony pudding cakes are simple to make, yet complex in texture.
content: Today‚Äôs as good a day as any to treat yourself to Melissa Clark‚Äôs lemon pudding cakes with sugared raspberries (above). The batter is simple, yet it yields two distinct textures ‚Äî spongy cake on top and custardy pudding on the bottom. That complexity may be why it was the most popular recipe this week. And if you‚Äôre looking for an entree to go with that dessert, try Susan Spungen‚Äôs vegetarian whole roasted cauliflower with pistachio pesto, Von Diaz‚Äôs pollo en fricas√© (from her collection of essential Puerto Rican recipes) or another savory dish from our list of the 10 most popular NYT Cooking recipes this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Stop the Executions, President Biden
description: Virginia‚Äôs move to end the death penalty was a welcome step. The administration can do more.
content: When Virginia abolished the death penalty this week, much of the response focused on what was new: the first Southern state to take this step, the state that has executed more people than any other in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India‚Äôs case surge hits highs not seen in months as festival season begins.
description: Infections are soaring in the country, which has severely curtailed exports of Covid-19 vaccines as it tries to prevent a second wave.
content: India, racing to contain a second wave of the coronavirus, on Sunday reported its biggest single-day spike since October ‚Äî 62,258 cases in the past 24 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Kozelj
title: Learning to Connect With My Male Friends
description: For some men, long-term, meaningful relationships are harder to build and maintain into adulthood.
content: I was 20 when I learned that my parents were splitting up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Just Give It a Go, Joe
description: It‚Äôs not the old days. The G.O.P. is not your friend, Mr. President.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Even though he doesn‚Äôt drink, Joe Biden was always bubbly at the holiday parties he gave at the vice president‚Äôs residence. He would lean in to tell you a good story or give you his unvarnished opinion about other top officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Showkat Nanda
title: Skiing in Himalayas Is ‚ÄòLike a Beautiful Dream,‚Äô Despite Conflict and Coronavirus
description: A Kashmir resort is welcoming the highest number of skiers in decades as Indians eager to get outdoors after lockdowns flock there even amid a simmering separatist movement and a security clampdown.
content: GULMARG, Kashmir ‚Äî As a soft snowfall blanketed everything around her, Nihad Ashraf Khan, a college student who had been cooped up for months because of the pandemic, ran up to her attic and almost frantically grabbed for her skis, poles, boots and goggles ‚Äî and headed immediately for the Himalayas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Jimmy Gamonet de los Heros Dies at 63; Helped Ballet in Miami
description: He was Miami City Ballet‚Äôs resident choreographer before establishing his own company. He later returned to his native Peru to run the National Ballet. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: The Original 20 Guant√°namo Detainees: A Roster, and Where They Are Now
description: Starting with the Bush administration, the United States has gradually transferred all but two of the first 20 prisoners at the wartime detention facility to other nations. Here‚Äôs who, and where, they are.
content: Mr. Ali, a Pakistani citizen, was among the earliest people repatriated from Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, at a time when the main prison facility, Camp Delta, held 680 detainees. The journalist Mark Bowden wrote that he traveled to Pakistan to meet some former Guant√°namo prisoners and found Mr. Ali and another detainee, who said they had not been abused in American custody ‚Äúexcept for some roughing up immediately after they were captured.‚Äù Both were in their 20s, he wrote in a later account, from tiny villages in the mountainous region of Pakistan where Al Qaeda and the Taliban hid, and he described them as ‚Äúhapless young Pakistanis‚Äù who were rounded up by ‚ÄúAfghani warlords‚Äù for a bounty of $4,000 a head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Can‚Äôt Take the Heat? A Taste for Spicy Foods Can Be Learned.
description: If you feel left out, here are tips for enjoying (or at least tolerating) the burn.
content: The sauces on the table remain untouched ‚Äî plain is fine, thank you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Howard Schnellenberger, College Coach Who Built Winners, Dies at 87
description: After assembling the formidable offense for the unbeaten 1972 Miami Dolphins, he breathed new life into football programs at two universities.
content: Howard Schnellenberger, who built the offense for the 1972 Miami Dolphins‚Äô unbeaten Super Bowl champions, then revived downtrodden football programs as head coach at the Universities of Miami and Louisville, died on Saturday. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: No Small Favor
description: You might need a hand with this Michael Hawkins puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE ‚Äî Cripes, this is one of those grids that makes me seriously consider chucking it all, finding a nice scaffolding and a sea sponge and meditatively cleaning walls for a few months in the sunshine. Although, that sun‚Äôs probably beating down pretty hard, and to restore archaeological treasures I probably need at least one advanced degree ‚Ä¶ so, crosswords it is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Argentina delays second doses to focus on broader vaccinations with first dose, fearing a variant-fueled wave.
description: The country plans to defer second shots for three months to give more residents first doses as variants drive case surges in neighboring Brazil, Chile and Paraguay.
content: BUENOS AIRES ‚Äî Argentina is delaying the administration of the second dose of Covid-19 vaccines for three months in an effort to ensure that as many people as possible get at least one dose amid a sluggish vaccination drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londo√±o, Let√≠cia Casado and Mauricio Lima
title: A Collapse Foretold: How Brazil‚Äôs Covid-19 Outbreak Overwhelmed Hospitals
description: The virus has killed more than 300,000 people in Brazil, its spread aided by a highly contagious variant, political infighting and distrust of science.
content: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil ‚Äî The patients began arriving at hospitals in Porto Alegre far sicker and younger than before. Funeral homes were experiencing a steady uptick in business, while exhausted doctors and nurses pleaded in February for a lockdown to save lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: For Michigan‚Äôs Players, Activism Has Been Season‚Äôs Theme
description: Forward Naz Hillmon and Coach Kim Barnes Arico determined that it was important to have frank, open, difficult conversations as a team about racism, which hadn‚Äôt happened before.
content: After No. 6 seed Michigan made its first round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. women‚Äôs basketball tournament, an emotional reaction by the all-American forward Naz Hillmon offered a window into a season that has been about much more than winning for the team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: A third of U.S. adults have received first doses, but New York and Arkansas lag in giving all adults vaccine access.
description: In the only other state that has not named a target date, Wyoming, adults already have full access in 20 of 23 counties.
content: The U.S. vaccination campaign is accelerating rapidly, with more than 91 million people ‚Äî roughly a third of the adult population ‚Äî having received at least one shot of a Covid-19 vaccination by Saturday. And nearly every state has announced that it will meet President Biden‚Äôs directive to make all adults eligible by May 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board and Damon Winter
title: Biden‚Äôs Chance to Save the Everglades
description: Reviving the South Florida ecosystem enjoys bipartisan support and deserves federal funding.
content: With passage of the Covid-19 relief bill behind it, the Biden administration will soon offer its encore, one or more big proposals reflecting President Biden‚Äôs multitrillion-dollar Build Back Better, which will enlarge government‚Äôs role in the American economy. Together, these budget requests will be bigger in dollar terms than the relief bill, will address daunting problems like infrastructure and climate change ‚Äî and, inevitably, will revive the partisan divide that plagues Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Easy to get, hard to repay: Predatory loans flourish in pandemic-gripped India.
description: These lenders don‚Äôt require credit scores or visits to a bank. But they charge high costs over a brief period. They also require access to a borrower‚Äôs phone, siphoning up contacts, photos, text messages, even battery percentage.
content: These lenders don‚Äôt require credit scores or visits to a bank. But they charge high costs over a brief period. They also require access to a borrower‚Äôs phone, siphoning up contacts, photos, text messages, even battery percentage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Stephanie Saul, Ali Watkins, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sara Aridi
title: An Immigrant Family Caught Up in a Distinctly American Tragedy
description: The suspect in the mass shooting at a Colorado supermarket came from an immigrant family that had achieved many of the outward signs of success. But their life in America had not been untroubled.
content: ARVADA, Colo. ‚Äî Two decades after they left Syria for a new home in the Rocky Mountains, it looked from the outside as if the Alissa family had made it in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: India‚Äôs News Upstarts Challenged Modi. New Rules Could Tame Them.
description: Online portals have practiced aggressive journalism in a mostly compliant media landscape. But trolls and the government could now be empowered to stop them.
content: NEW DELHI ‚Äî Narendra Modi, India‚Äôs prime minister, has cultivated and cowed large parts of the country‚Äôs normally raucous news media in recent years as part of a broader campaign against dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: State lawmakers take aim at the emergency powers governors have relied on in the pandemic.
description: Around 300 proposals to curb governors‚Äô emergency powers have won approval or are awaiting action in state legislatures. Almost all were written by Republicans, but the targets are governors of both parties.
content: When the pandemic began, the nation‚Äôs governors suited up for a new role as state bodyguards, issuing emergency orders to shutter schools, close cinemas and ban indoor dining in an effort to curb a mushrooming threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler and Lauren Hirsch
title: Wall Street‚Äôs Sleepless Nights
description: Junior bankers are burning out. What should banks do about it?
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don‚Äôt already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta, Geneva Abdul, Manuela Andreoni and Veronica Penney
title: After a year of the pandemic, public transit around the world is hanging by a thread.
description: In London, Piccadilly Circus station is nearly empty on a weekday morning, while in Delhi, the Metro ferries fewer than half of the riders it used to. In Rio, bus drivers are on strike, and in New York City, subway traffic is at just a third of normal volume.
content: In London, Piccadilly Circus station is nearly empty on a weekday morning, while in Delhi, the Metro ferries fewer than half of the riders it used to. In Rio, bus drivers are on strike, and in New York City, subway traffic is at just a third of normal volume.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: So, What‚Äôs Your ‚ÄòFauxmorbidity‚Äô?
description: People are racing to get vaccinated ‚Äî even those who don‚Äôt yet technically qualify. And that‚Äôs good news.
content: After Covid-19 vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna were approved for use in late 2020, anecdotes proliferated about rich people finding ways to jump the distribution priority line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Baylor Passes Biggest Test of Tournament and Oral Roberts Falters
description: The Bears won a tight, physical game to reach a regional final. Oral Roberts allowed Arkansas to come back, then missed a shot at the buzzer that could have been a winner.
content: INDIANAPOLIS ‚Äî This men‚Äôs college basketball season featured an early-season delight for the sport‚Äôs aficionados, a neutral site matchup of the teams that prognosticators tabbed as the best in the country ‚Äî the highflying Gonzaga Bulldogs against the slick but dogged Baylor Bears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tailyr Irvine and Gillian Friedman
title: Was Keeping Tourists Out the Only Way to Survive?
description: On the Blackfeet Reservation, at the border of Glacier National Park, businesses needed visitors. The tribe needed to protect people from Covid.
content: ST. MARY, Mont. ‚Äî In a regular spring season at Johnson‚Äôs of St. Mary, the R. V.s would be pulling into the more than 150 sites with sweeping views of Glacier National Park. Campsites would start filling up. The kitchen would start churning out homemade soup and bread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azadeh Moaveni and Sussan Tahmasebi
title: How Sanctions Hurt Iranian Women
description: The decimation of the economy since the U.S. left the nuclear deal is crippling the people who have been working for reform.
content: A few weeks after the Trump administration withdrew from the Iran nuclear deal in May 2018, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo condemned ‚Äúbrutal men of the regime‚Äù in Tehran for oppressing Iranian women who were demanding their rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: She Vanished Decades Ago. Her Children Just Learned She Had Been Killed.
description: William Heiser Jr. said his father had told him and his sister that their mother, Marie Heiser, had ‚Äújust packed up her stuff and left.‚Äù
content: One day, about a half-century ago, William Heiser Jr. came home from boarding school to find that his mother was gone.  His father, William Sr., a former police officer, told him and his sister that their mother had walked out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julfikar Ali Manik and Emily Schmall
title: At Least 10 Killed in Protests Against Modi‚Äôs Visit to Bangladesh
description: Islamist religious processions in different parts of the country became the scenes of deadly violence, marring 50th anniversary celebrations.
content: DHAKA, Bangladesh ‚Äî At least 10 people were killed and dozens injured in protests against a visit by Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India to Bangladesh as part of celebrations for the country‚Äôs 50th anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: ‚ÄòA Very Big Problem.‚Äô Giant Ship in the Suez Remains Stuck.
description: A small Egyptian village has a front-row seat to the unfolding effort to dislodge the container ship that ran aground in the canal, holding up $10 billion in global trade every day.
content: MANSHIYET RUGOLA, Egypt ‚Äî The gargantuan container ship that has blocked world trade by getting stuck aslant the Suez Canal has towered over Umm Gaafar‚Äôs dusty brick house for five days now, humming its deep mechanical hum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: We Want Our Friends Back! (But Which Ones?)
description: The pandemic shrank many social circles to a skeleton crew. Maybe that‚Äôs not such a bad thing.
content: It‚Äôs not like 2020 was a year without friends. We raised a toast on Zoom birthday parties, organized trivia nights on Google Meet and spent more time than ever waiting in lines, a great place to make new friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: Why the internet loves the Suez Canal stuck ship saga.
description: The stranding of the Ever Given in the Suez Canal this week became a  fully fledged internet moment.
content: It‚Äôs a moment that has managed to wrap Bernie Sanders‚Äôs mittens, jokes about poor driving skills and timeless office humor into one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Swiss Billionaire Joins the Bidding for Tribune Publishing
description: The philanthropist Hansj√∂rg Wyss has teamed with the Maryland hotel executive Stewart Bainum in a bid to upend Alden Global Capital‚Äôs plan to acquire the newspaper chain.
content: An octogenarian Swiss billionaire who makes his home in Wyoming and has donated hundreds of millions to environmental causes is a surprise new player in the bidding for Tribune Publishing, the major newspaper chain that until recently seemed destined to end up in the hands of a New York hedge fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Racist Moments in WWE Catalog Vanish in Move to Streaming Platform
description: Peacock, NBCUniversal‚Äôs streaming service, is now showing old and new episodes of WWE Network wrestling. Some troubling segments in the network‚Äôs history disappeared in the transfer.
content: Fans of the WWE Network have seen and heard racist tropes in the ring for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: As Pandemic Upends Teaching, Fewer Students Want to Pursue It
description: Disruptions to education during the pandemic are turning people away from a profession that was already struggling to attract new recruits.
content: Kianna Ameni-Melvin‚Äôs parents used to tell her that there wasn‚Äôt much money to be made in education. But it was easy enough for her to tune them out as she enrolled in an education studies program, with her mind set on teaching high school special education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Expecting N.C.A.A. Miracles, the Oral Roberts Golden Eagles Make a Run
description: The No. 15 seed from Tulsa, Okla., plays No. 3 Arkansas on Saturday, and the players will try to show that they are not done yet.
content: INDIANAPOLIS ‚Äî This is the point, the second weekend of the N.C.A.A. men‚Äôs basketball tournament, when the side door is opened and uninvited guests are unceremoniously ushered out. So the time is nigh to introduce the Oral Roberts basketball team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Glynn S. Lunney Dies at 84; Oversaw NASA Flights From Mission Control
description: He was hailed for leading the rescue of Apollo 13 astronauts when their spacecraft was rocked by an explosion en route to the moon, and for helping guide them home.
content: Glynn S. Lunney, the NASA flight director who played a major role in America‚Äôs space program and was hailed for his leadership in the rescue of three Apollo 13 astronauts when their spacecraft was rocked by an explosion en route to the moon in 1973, died on March 19 at his home in Clear Lake, Texas. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: Under Biden, Democrats Are Poised to Raise Taxes on Business and the Rich
description: The president‚Äôs infrastructure proposals are likely to require trillions of dollars in new tax revenue. They also give liberals a chance to address what they call the failures of Republican tax cuts.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Democrats have spent the last several years clamoring to raise taxes on corporations and the rich, seeing that as a necessary antidote to widening economic inequality and a rebuke of President Donald J. Trump‚Äôs signature tax cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grull√≥n Paz
title: The E.U. approves more vaccine production sites amid lagging inoculation efforts.
description: A top European drug agency gave a green light to new plants in the Netherlands, Germany and Switzerland for AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines.
content: The European Union‚Äôs stumbling Covid-19 vaccination drive, badly shaken by the recent AstraZeneca safety scare, got a boost Friday from the European Medicines Agency, which approved new AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccine production sites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon get us to get the picture. üòï üß† ü§î üí° üòÅ
content: ACROSTIC ‚Äî Today‚Äôs excerpt is one for my üíñ, or soul, because I am a great fan (ü¶ö) and scholar (üìú) of its subject: the emoji. I‚Äôm fond of texting over calling and good-natured, illustrative imagery over, um, punctuation, and I welcome the emoji‚Äôs creep into professional life, as appalling as that might sound to some. (I hope I didn‚Äôt just give the whole puzzle away, especially if you‚Äôre still stuck thinking those two words with ‚ÄúJ‚Äù second-to-last could be banjos.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: A Downtown Gallerist Spreads His Wings
description: Alexander Shulan runs Lomex, a New York gallery that nurtures emerging artists.
content: Name: Alexander Shulan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Insurgents Seize Mozambique Town, Killing Several People; Fate of Hundreds Unknown
description: The attack by hundreds of militants trapped nearly 200 people, including foreign workers, in a hotel in Palma, Mozambique, site of a major gas project.
content: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa ‚Äî Insurgents seized control of much of a town in Mozambique on Saturday, after a three-day siege that has left at least several people dead and hundreds of other civilians unaccounted for as government forces try to regain control, according to private security contractors in East Africa and news reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Mother of 6 Fatally Shot in Road Rage Episode, Police Say
description: Officials said a driver fired multiple times into the passenger door of a couple‚Äôs car after they came close to a vehicle while merging into a lane in North Carolina.
content: A mother of six children was fatally shot in North Carolina during a case of road rage on Thursday as the woman and her husband were on a getaway trip, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Steven Lee Myers
title: China, With $400 Billion Iran Deal, Could Deepen Influence in Mideast
description: The countries signed a sweeping pact on Saturday that calls for heavy Chinese investments in Iran over 25 years in exchange for oil ‚Äî a step that could ease Iran‚Äôs international isolation.
content: China agreed to invest $400 billion in Iran over 25 years in exchange for a steady supply of oil to fuel its growing economy under a sweeping economic and security agreement signed on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: They Were Guant√°namo‚Äôs First Detainees. Here‚Äôs Where They Are Now.
description: The Pentagon called the first 20 prisoners sent to Guant√°namo in 2002 ‚Äúthe worst of the worst.‚Äù Just two remain there. Others are spread around the world ‚Äî including four senior Taliban figures.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî On Jan. 11, 2002, at the desolate air strip at Guant√°namo Bay, United States Marines escorted 20 prisoners clad in orange uniforms from an Air Force cargo plane ‚Äî ‚Äúthe worst of the worst,‚Äù the Pentagon called them ‚Äî making them the first inmates of the wartime detention center that remains open to this day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: 2 Killed, One of Them by Police, in ‚ÄòChaotic Night‚Äô in Virginia Beach
description: A man was fatally shot by an officer and a woman was killed by stray gunfire in separate shootings on Friday night, the police said. Eight other people were wounded.
content: A police officer fatally shot a man in an encounter that capped a chaotic night of violence on Friday in Virginia Beach, where a woman was also killed by stray gunfire, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Serbia Hails Chinese Companies as Saviors, but Locals Chafe at Costs
description: While the government is welcoming Chinese investors to save moribund businesses and bring much-needed capital, many Serbians are complaining of environmental and political impacts.
content: METOVNICA, Serbia ‚Äî The well in the retired couple‚Äôs yard, their only source of clean water, began to dry up two years ago. Last year, dead fish started washing up on the banks of the river that runs by their home in a bucolic village in southeastern Serbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: Under Biden, Diplomacy Is an Attractive Career Again
description: Interest in becoming a diplomat has grown, and President Biden‚Äôs outreach to other nations is appealing to aspiring diplomats, many of whom felt alienated by Trump policies.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî When Aaron Luce quit the Foreign Service in 2019, President Donald J. Trump loomed large in his mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Aims to Be the Anti-Amazon of E-Commerce. It Has a Long Way to Go.
description: Google presents itself to independent sellers as cheaper and less restrictive. But it is not clear whether it can change people‚Äôs habits of going straight to Amazon.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. ‚Äî Google tried to copy Amazon‚Äôs playbook to become the shopping hub of the internet, with little success. Now it is trying something different: the anti-Amazon strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: For Them, New York City Will Never Be The Same
description: The city may be only months from seeming like its old self. But the pandemic has changed many lives.
content: The old job, the old office, the old week ‚Äî for many New Yorkers, the possibility of the return of something resembling their old life appears finally within reach. For them, the year of the pandemic was a blip, a pause, however frustrating, in their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Over the Moon
description: Olivia Mitra Framke wafts us into space.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE ‚Äî My impulse is to put a bright, happy photo on a column about a bright, happy puzzle, but that windblown little terrier in the gloaming seems a good choice today (although technically it‚Äôs the backdrop that‚Äôs more relevant). This poetic grid, our fourth Sunday from Olivia Mitra Framke, takes flight from its title, a common expression, and gives us a twist that will appeal to all of the night owls, werewolves and Olivia Mitra Framke fans. (I am two for three, but feel free to aroooooo.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Images From a ‚ÄòDay of Shame‚Äô in Myanmar, With Scores Shot Dead
description: Children, including a 5-year-old-boy, were among those killed on Saturday as the country‚Äôs security forces cracked down on nationwide protests against a coup. A New York Times photographer was there.
content: In one of the deadliest days in Myanmar since the Feb. 1 military coup, dozens of people, and perhaps more than 100, were killed on Saturday by security forces cracking down on nationwide protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Does a Baby Bust End?
description: Three scenarios for a more fertile American future.
content: The declining American birthrate is a frequent preoccupation of this column, and over the years that I‚Äôve been writing about the problem it‚Äôs only gotten worse, with the apparent Covid-19 baby bust a punctuation mark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Adorante
title: The go-to vaccine outfit? Dolly Parton set the style with a cold-shoulder top.
description: Look out, Zoom shirt. Here comes the vaccine top.
content: Look out, Zoom shirt. Here comes the vaccine top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Sharon Osbourne Leaves ‚ÄòThe Talk,‚Äô CBS Says
description: The television host had defended Piers Morgan, a journalist who questioned an account by Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, about life in Britain‚Äôs royal family.
content: Sharon Osbourne, a television host who faced criticism for defending contentious remarks by the British journalist Piers Morgan about Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, has decided to leave ‚ÄúThe Talk,‚Äù the U.S. daytime talk show where she worked for more than a decade, CBS said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Charli Collier of Texas Honors Her Father‚Äôs Memory With Resilience
description: The Texas center, projected to be the No. 1 pick in the 2021 W.N.B.A. draft, got through a difficult year by drawing strength from her family.
content: Charli Collier has spent her last season in college basketball adjusting to a new coach, to a coronavirus-safe form of training, to disrupted classes and to conferring with her teammates over video calls. All the while, she coped with the expectation that she would become the top pick in the next W.N.B.A. draft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Craig muMs Grant, Actor and Slam Poet, Dies at 52
description: He was a star of the HBO series ‚ÄúOz‚Äù under the name muMs, which he also used on the poetry circuit both before and after finding success on television.
content: Craig muMs Grant‚Äôs biggest success as an actor was the role of Poet on the HBO prison drama ‚ÄúOz,‚Äù but fans of that series were accustomed to seeing him credited simply as muMs. It was a name he adopted as a young man when he was exploring rap and slam poetry, influences that he said changed his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Isabella Kwai
title: Suicide and Self-Harm: Bereaved Families Count the Costs of Lockdowns
description: The psychological toll on young people of months in isolation and great global suffering is becoming more clear after successive lockdowns.
content: LONDON ‚Äî Sunny, driven and with a new engineering master‚Äôs degree in hand, Joshua Morgan was hopeful he could find a job despite the pandemic, move out of his mother‚Äôs house and begin his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: Broadcasting ‚Äòthe Shock, the Horror, the Outrage‚Äô Live, Again and Again
description: After Columbine, the media faced criticism for focusing on the assailants rather than on the victims. A lot has changed since 1999 ‚Äî except the need to cover the tragedies in the first place.
content: Last week, the CNN anchor Brianna Keilar found herself, for the second time in under a week, guiding viewers through the grim ritual of trying, and failing, to make sense of another mass shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees‚Äô Voit Out for First Month of Season With Knee Injury
description: The major league home run champion had been playing through soreness in spring training and but will opt now to have his knee repaired.
content: Luke Voit, the Yankees‚Äô first baseman and the major-league home run champion last season, will miss at least the first month of the season to have knee surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Stop It With ‚ÄòGun Control.‚Äô Enough Already.
description: Language matters. This language doesn‚Äôt help.
content: The words tumbled readily from Josh Hawley‚Äôs lips as he argued for doing little in the wake of the Atlanta and Boulder, Colo., massacres.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: Eurovision Song Contest Disqualifies Belarus Over Political Lyrics
description: The song‚Äôs lyrics were found to violate the competition‚Äôs rules in what critics called an endorsement of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko‚Äôs crackdown on antigovernment protests.
content: The long-running unrest in Belarus has spilled over into this year‚Äôs Eurovision Song Contest, with organizers ejecting the country from the competition for songs found to have repeatedly violated rules barring political content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: A district judge in Texas rules that Austin can keep its mask mandate for now.
description: The state‚Äôs attorney general, Ken Paxton, is expected to appeal.
content: A district judge in Texas has allowed Austin and the surrounding Travis County to keep requiring masks, weeks after Gov. Greg Abbott ended the state‚Äôs mask mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Indiana Upsets No. 1 Seed North Carolina State at N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: The Wolfpack are the first No. 1 seed to be knocked out of this tournament, in the round of 16. Another No. 1, UConn, moved on to the round of 8.
content: SAN ANTONIO ‚Äî Indiana knocked top-seeded North Carolina State out of the N.C.A.A. women‚Äôs tournament on Saturday in the round of 16, 73-70, making the Wolfpack the first No. 1 seed to fall from the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Can New Gun Violence Research Find a Path Around the Political Stalemate?
description: Congress quashed funding for C.D.C. gun violence research 25 years ago. But an extraordinary friendship between an agency scientist and the ‚Äúpoint man‚Äù for the N.R.A. helped bring the money back.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Dr. Bindi J. Naik-Mathuria, a pediatric trauma surgeon at Texas Children‚Äôs Hospital who grew tired of seeing toddlers die of gunshot wounds, has a $684,000 federal grant to track every gun-related death and injury in Houston. The goal: identify and address ‚Äúhot spots‚Äù the way epidemiologists track and contain the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Should Only Vaccinated People Be Allowed to Use the Gym?
description: Apartment buildings with gyms may want to combat the coronavirus, but banning unvaccinated residents from working out is a perilous idea.
content: Q: My co-op‚Äôs gym has been closed since last March. The board recently decided to reopen the gym for those shareholders who are fully vaccinated against Covid-19. All others are still prohibited from using the gym. Is this legal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: He‚Äôs a Famous Evangelical Preacher, but His Kids Wish He‚Äôd Pipe Down
description: The Rev. Rick Joyner has called on Christians to arm themselves for civil war. But his children would be on the other side.
content: The Rev. Rick Joyner is a famous evangelical leader who has called on Christians to arm themselves for an inevitable civil war against liberals, who he suggests are allies of the devil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso and Nailah Morgan
title: Dozens Killed in One of Myanmar‚Äôs Deadliest Days Since February Coup
description: Children and bystanders were among the dozens shot and killed in Myanmar on Saturday as the security forces cracked down on protests against the February military coup. On the same day, a parade honored the army.
content: Children and bystanders were among the dozens shot and killed in Myanmar on Saturday as the security forces cracked down on protests against the February military coup. On the same day, a parade honored the army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Associated Press
title: Vessels Accumulate as Cargo Ship Remains Lodged in Suez Canal
description: The Ever Given container ship on Saturday remained lodged in the Suez Canal in Egypt, where it had been stuck since Tuesday. Authorities said the jam has caused a backlog of more than 300 ships waiting to cross.
content: The Ever Given container ship on Saturday remained lodged in the Suez Canal in Egypt, where it had been stuck since Tuesday. Authorities said the jam has caused a backlog of more than 300 ships waiting to cross.

title: Corrections: March 27, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 27, 2021.
content: An article on Thursday about the Israeli election misstated the turnout. It was 67.4 percent, not 66.7 percent.
